dex.name: Decentralized Exchanges
dex.explanation: DA requirements for DEXs are driven by order book updates, trade execution speed, liquidity pool rebalancing, and market dynamics. High-frequency trading, flash crashes, and large market movements can cause significant DA spikes.

metrics.name: Order Book Management

subMetrics.name: Order Placement Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Across popular trading pairs the market sees 10 new limit orders per second, requiring frequent order book updates.
Each order placement is 250 bytes, accounting for metadata, signatures, and potential cross-chain information.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During a market crash, order placement rate spikes to 50 per second, causing a surge in DA demand.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the rate at which new orders are placed on the order book.
Assumes 100 active agents trading across multiple pairs, with varying levels of trading frequency and sophistication.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased market complexity and cross-chain interactions.

subMetrics.name: Order Cancellation Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Trading agents cancel about 1 orders per second as part of regular strategy adjustments.
Each order cancellation is 200 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A false rumor causes panic, leading to 50 order cancellations per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the rate at which orders are canceled.
Assumes a mix of manual traders and basic trading bots among the 100 agents, with moderate order adjustment frequencies.
Scales linearly with the number of agents, but at a slightly lower rate for a large number of agents.

subMetrics.name: Order Book Depth
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
The order book maintains 2 updates per second, requiring constant updates.
Each order book update is 750 bytes, accounting for more complex order book structures in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Market makers add liquidity, expanding the order book to 20 updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Represents the number of orders at various price levels in the order book.
Assumes moderate liquidity across popular trading pairs, with a few dedicated market makers among the 100 agents.
Scales exponentially due to increasing complexity and interactions across multiple chains.

subMetrics.name: Order Modification Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Traders modify about 3 orders per second to adjust their positions.
Each order modification is 250 bytes, accounting for additional metadata and cross-chain information.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During high volatility, order modifications spike to 30 per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the rate at which existing orders are modified (e.g., changing price or quantity).
Assumes occasional order modifications by a subset of the 100 agents.
Scales linearly with the number of agents, with a slight increase in rate for a large number of agents.

subMetrics.name: Order Matching Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
The exchange matches 5 orders per second during normal trading.
Each order match is 400 bytes, accounting for more complex matching scenarios in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A sudden market movement leads to 25 order matches per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency at which orders are matched and removed from the order book.
Assumes regular order matching activity suitable for 100 agents.
Scales exponentially due to higher frequency of matches as the number of agents increases.

metrics.explanation:
Order book management DA increases due to:
• Higher frequency of order placements and cancellations
• Deeper order books requiring more data storage and updates
• Need for real-time synchronization across all nodes
• Increased complexity in maintaining order book integrity during high volatility

metrics.name: Trade Execution

subMetrics.name: Transaction Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
The exchange processes 5 trades per second during normal market conditions.
Each trade transaction is 350 bytes, accounting for additional metadata, signatures, and potential cross-chain information.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A major news event causes trading volume to spike to 100 trades per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the number of trades executed per second.
Assumes standard transaction processing capabilities suitable for 100 agents, with occasional spikes in trading activity.
Scales exponentially with the number of agents, but with a slightly reduced rate for a large number of agents.

subMetrics.name: Slippage Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Slippage is calculated for 5 trades per second for active trading pairs.
Each slippage data point is 500 bytes, accounting for detailed slippage information across multiple chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High volatility requires slippage calculations for 200 trades per second to protect traders.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the difference between the expected and actual trade prices.
Assumes basic slippage protection mechanisms suitable for the trading volume generated by 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly with the number of trades, reflecting increased market complexity without full exponential growth.

subMetrics.name: Trade Confirmation Time
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
5 trade confirmations are processed per second under normal conditions.
Each trade confirmation is 100 bytes, accounting for additional confirmation details in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During peak trading, confirmation rate increases to 100 per second due to network congestion.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the time it takes for a trade to be confirmed.
Assumes regular confirmation processes suitable for 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly with the number of trades, reflecting increased complexity without full exponential growth.

subMetrics.name: Trade Settlement Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
5 trades are settled per second in regular conditions.
Each trade settlement is 250 bytes, accounting for more complex settlement processes in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High trading volume requires settlement of 100 trades per second to prevent backlogs.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the rate at which trades are settled and final.
Assumes periodic settlement processes suitable for the trading volume of 100 agents.
Scales exponentially with the number of trades, but with a slightly reduced rate for a large number of agents.

metrics.explanation:
Trade execution DA spikes due to:
• Dramatic increase in transaction volume during volatile periods
• Larger trade sizes requiring more data to process and verify
• More frequent and complex slippage calculations
• Need for faster block creation and propagation to handle increased load

metrics.name: Liquidity Pool Updates

subMetrics.name: Pool Rebalancing
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Liquidity pools rebalance 0.25 time per second to maintain target ratios.
Each pool rebalancing action is 600 bytes, accounting for more complex rebalancing data in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid price changes force pool rebalancing 25 times per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of rebalancing the liquidity pool.
Assumes moderate-sized liquidity pools suitable for the trading volume from 100 agents, with periodic rebalancing to maintain ratios.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and frequency of rebalancing in a multi-chain environment.

subMetrics.name: Liquidity Provider Actions
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
2 liquidity providers adjust their positions per second.
Each liquidity provider action (add/remove liquidity) is 200 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A yield farming opportunity causes 20 LP adjustments per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Tracks actions by liquidity providers such as adding or removing liquidity.
Assumes a small portion of the 100 agents are active liquidity providers, with occasional position adjustments based on market conditions.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and frequency of liquidity provision across multiple chains.

subMetrics.name: Automated Market Making
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
AMM curves are updated 1 time per second under normal conditions.
Each automated market making action is 350 bytes, accounting for more complex AMM operations in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Extreme volatility requires 100 AMM curve updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the activity of the automated market maker algorithm.
Assumes basic AMM algorithms suitable for handling the trading volume and market dynamics created by 100 agents.
Scales exponentially with the number of agents due to the increased complexity of balancing liquidity across multiple chains and pools.

subMetrics.name: Fee Calculation and Distribution
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Fees are calculated and distributed 1 time per second.
Each fee calculation and distribution action is 300 bytes, accounting for more complex fee structures in a multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High trading volume requires 50 fee calculations and distributions per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of fee calculations and distributions to liquidity providers.
Assumes basic fee calculation and distribution mechanisms suitable for 100 agents.
Scales exponentially with the number of agents due to the increased complexity of fee structures and distribution across multiple chains.

subMetrics.name: Price Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Asset prices are updated 2 times per second.
Each price update is 150 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid market movements require 100 price updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of updates to pool prices based on market conditions.
Assumes regular price update mechanisms suitable for 100 agents.
Scales exponentially with the number of agents due to the increased frequency and complexity of price updates required in a multi-chain environment.

metrics.explanation:
Liquidity pool updates require more DA due to:
• Frequent rebalancing of pools to maintain desired ratios
• Increased liquidity provider activities (adding/removing liquidity)
• More complex and frequent automated market making calculations
• Need for real-time updates of pool states across the network

metrics.name: Price Oracle Management

subMetrics.name: Oracle Data Submissions
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Price oracles submit 10 updates per second for major trading pairs.
Each oracle data submission is 200 bytes, including asset identifier, price, timestamp, and provider signature.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During high volatility, oracles submit 200 updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of price data submissions from oracle providers.
Assumes regular oracle data submissions suitable for 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly due to increased complexity and the need for frequent updates as more agents participate, with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Oracle Provider Reputation Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Oracle provider reputations are updated 1 time per second based on accuracy.
Each reputation update is 300 bytes, including provider identifier, new reputation score, and supporting data.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A potential oracle attack leads to 10 reputation updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of updates to the reputation scores of oracle providers.
Assumes basic reputation management for oracle providers suitable for 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly as the number of providers increases, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Consensus Mechanism Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
The oracle consensus mechanism is updated 0.1 times per second.
Each consensus mechanism update is 500 bytes, including new parameters, justification, and activation timestamp.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A critical vulnerability requires 10 consensus updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of updates to the consensus mechanism for aggregating oracle data.
Assumes infrequent consensus mechanism updates suitable for 100 agents.
Scales logarithmically as the system becomes more stable with increased scale.

subMetrics.name: Cross-Chain Price Synchronization
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Cross-chain price data is synchronized 5 times per second.
Each synchronization event is 400 bytes, including price data for multiple assets, chain identifiers, and synchronization metadata.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High cross-chain trading activity requires 100 synchronizations per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of synchronization events to ensure price consistency across chains.
Assumes regular cross-chain price synchronization suitable for 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly as the number of interconnected chains increases, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Price oracle management DA requirements increase due to:
• More frequent and precise oracle price updates
• Increased complexity in managing oracle provider reputations
• Need for consistent consensus across multiple chains
• Challenges in maintaining price consistency across interconnected networks

scenarios.title: Flash Loan Attacks or Large-Scale Arbitrage Operations
scenarios.analysis: Rapid, simultaneous trades by millions of AI agents cause significant state changes across liquidity pools.
scenarios.implications: Immediate burst capacity and fast state propagation are crucial to mitigate systemic risks and maintain market stability.

scenarios.title: Launch of Popular New Token Pairs
scenarios.analysis: A surge in account creations, order placements, and liquidity as millions of agents engage with new tokens.
scenarios.implications: Scalable onboarding and efficient order book management are essential to handle the surge and prevent network congestion.

scenarios.title: Market-Wide High Trading Volumes
scenarios.analysis: Increased trading across multiple pairs as AI agents optimize trades, leading to a massive network load.
scenarios.implications: System-wide scalability and efficient state management are vital for maintaining synchronization and seamless trading experiences.

scenarios.title: Sudden Market Crashes Triggering Mass Order Cancellations
scenarios.analysis: Panic-driven cancellations by agents responding to market downturns, leading to volatile order books.
scenarios.implications: High DA capacity is necessary to process cancellations swiftly and prevent cascading failures in market operations.

scenarios.title: Coordinated AI-Driven Trading Strategies
scenarios.analysis: Coordinated actions by AI agents executing complex trading algorithms increase the frequency and complexity of transactions.
scenarios.implications: Robust DA systems are required to support rapid transaction processing and ensure market efficiency.

scenarios.title: New Protocol Upgrades or Forks
scenarios.analysis: Protocol changes lead to increased activity as agents adapt to new features or resolve inconsistencies.
scenarios.implications: Enhanced DA is needed to ensure smooth transitions and prevent data lags during upgrades.

lendingBorrowing.name: Lending and Borrowing
lendingBorrowing.explanation: DA requirements for lending and borrowing protocols are driven by interest rate updates, collateral value fluctuations, and loan position changes. Market volatility and large-scale user actions can lead to sudden spikes in DA needs.

metrics.name: Interest Rate Management

subMetrics.name: Rate Calculation Frequency
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Interest rates are recalculated 1 time per second based on utilization rates.
Each rate calculation update is 250 bytes, accounting for more complex calculations involving multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During high volatility, rates are updated 20 times per second to reflect rapid market changes.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures how often interest rates are recalculated.
Assumes a lending pool with moderate activity from 100 agents, requiring periodic rate adjustments.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and frequency of calculations in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.

subMetrics.name: Market Data Integration
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
External price feeds are queried 1 time per second to adjust interest rates.
Each market data update is 600 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive market data across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Price feeds are queried 50 times per second during market turbulence.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of market data updates integrated into the system.
Assumes integration with a few key price oracles, suitable for the scale of 100 agents.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and volume of market data across multiple assets and chains.

subMetrics.name: User Notification System
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Users receive 1 update per second on their loan interest rates.
Each user notification remains at 100 bytes, as the basic structure of notifications doesn't change significantly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time notifications are sent 10 times per second for every rate change during volatile periods.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of notifications sent to users regarding interest rate changes.
Assumes a basic notification system capable of handling updates for 100 users.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to the increased number of users who need to be notified, but with optimizations for large-scale operations.

metrics.explanation:
Interest rate management DA increases due to:
• More frequent rate recalculations in volatile markets
• Integration of real-time market data from multiple sources
• Increased user notifications about rate changes
• Need for rapid propagation of new rates across the network

metrics.name: Collateral Management

subMetrics.name: Collateral Value Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Collateral values are updated 1 time per second under normal conditions.
Each collateral value update is 850 bytes, accounting for more complex updates involving multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During market crashes, collateral values are updated 10 times per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of updates to collateral values.
Assumes a moderate range of collateral types used by 100 agents, requiring regular value updates.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and frequency of updates in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.

subMetrics.name: Liquidation Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Liquidation thresholds are checked 1 time per second for all positions.
Each liquidation monitoring update is 450 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive monitoring across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous real-time monitoring results in 10 checks per second of all positions near liquidation thresholds.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of monitoring for potential liquidations.
Assumes a liquidation engine capable of monitoring positions for 100 users with varying collateral ratios.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and volume of monitoring across multiple assets and chains.

subMetrics.name: Collateral Withdrawal Requests
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Users perform 1 collateral withdrawal per second.
Each withdrawal request is 400 bytes, as the basic structure of requests doesn't change significantly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in withdrawal requests results in 5 requests per second as users seek to reduce exposure during market stress.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of requests to withdraw collateral.
Assumes occasional collateral withdrawals by a subset of the 100 users, with increased activity during market stress.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity of cross-chain operations and enhanced security measures.

subMetrics.name: Collateral Health Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Collateral health is monitored 5 times per second for all active positions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During market volatility, collateral health is monitored 25 times per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the continuous monitoring of the health/status of collateral beyond just value updates.
Assumes regular health checks for collateral owned by 100 users, with capacity for more frequent updates when needed.
Each health monitoring update is 350 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive health monitoring.
Scales superlinearly as the number of agents and the complexity of monitoring increases, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Collateral management DA spikes due to:
• Rapid and frequent updates of collateral asset prices
• Increased liquidation events requiring immediate action
• Higher frequency of collateral swaps and adjustments
• Need for real-time risk assessment of collateralized positions

metrics.name: Loan Position Tracking

subMetrics.name: Position Health Calculation
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Loan health is recalculated 1 time per second for all active positions.
Each position health calculation is 1300 bytes, accounting for more complex calculations involving multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Health scores are updated 15 times per second during high volatility.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of calculating the health of loan positions.
Assumes regular health calculations for loans held by 100 users, with varying loan sizes and collateral types.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity and frequency of calculations in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.

subMetrics.name: Loan Origination and Closure
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
New loans and repayments are processed at a rate of 0.1 per second.
Each loan origination or closure operation is 1700 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive processes across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in new loans and emergency closures during market events leads to 20 processes per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of loan originations and closures.
Assumes moderate loan origination and closure activity among 100 users, with occasional spikes.
Scales superlinearly with the number of agents due to increased complexity of cross-chain operations and enhanced security measures.

subMetrics.name: Historical Data Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Loan history is compressed and archived 0.1 time per second.
Each historical data management operation is 8000 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive data management across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Increased granularity of historical data during volatile periods requires 5 compressions and archives per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of managing and updating historical loan data.
Assumes basic historical data management for 100 users, with capacity for increased detail during significant market events.
Scales logarithmically with the number of agents due to optimizations and compression techniques in data management systems at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Loan position tracking DA requirements increase due to:
• More frequent recalculation of loan health metrics
• Increased loan origination and closure activities during market events
• Need for more detailed historical data for risk assessment
• Real-time updates of user dashboards and risk management systems

scenarios.title: Rapid Asset Price Changes Across Chains
scenarios.daScaling: Exponential, affected by the number of loans and chains
scenarios.analysis: Swift price changes trigger mass recalculations of collateral values, impacting liquidation processes.
scenarios.implications: Ultra-fast cross-chain communication and state synchronization are crucial to prevent liquidation delays and protect system integrity.

scenarios.title: Large-Scale Borrowing/Repayment by AI Agents
scenarios.daScaling: Exponential, influenced by agent activities and strategies
scenarios.analysis: Massive transactions by AI agents require rapid DA to ensure accurate loan state updates and prevent market distortions.
scenarios.implications: Real-time state management is essential to maintain system stability and prevent arbitrage failures and cascading effects.

scenarios.title: Dynamic Interest Rates with Credit Scores
scenarios.analysis: Interest rate fluctuations based on credit scores require continuous data updates and risk assessments.
scenarios.implications: Privacy-preserving DA solutions are necessary to handle sensitive credit data while ensuring consistent risk management and user trust.

scenarios.title: Sudden Liquidity Withdrawals
scenarios.analysis: Mass withdrawals by agents responding to market volatility can strain liquidity pools.
scenarios.implications: Immediate DA is required to update liquidity states and maintain operational efficiency, preventing potential liquidity crises.

scenarios.title: Collateral Value Manipulation
scenarios.analysis: Manipulative activities affecting collateral values require continuous monitoring and rapid DA.
scenarios.implications: Enhanced DA systems are crucial for real-time detection and response, ensuring the integrity of lending protocols.

cdpAndStablecoin.name: CDPs and Stablecoins
cdpAndStablecoin.explanation: DA requirements for CDP and stablecoin systems are driven by collateral ratio management, stablecoin minting/burning activities, and complex governance decisions. Extreme market movements and large-scale user actions can cause system-wide DA spikes.

metrics.name: Collateral Ratio Management

subMetrics.name: Collateral Price Oracles
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Collateral prices are updated 2 times per second from multiple oracles.
Each price update is 300 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive price data across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Oracle updates occur 100 times per second during high volatility.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of price updates from oracles.
Assumes integration with a few reliable price oracles, suitable for managing CDPs of 100 users.
Scales superlinearly due to increased complexity and the need for frequent updates as more agents participate, with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: CDP Health Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
CDP health is recalculated 5 times per second for all positions.
Each health monitoring update is 300 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous real-time monitoring results in 50 calculations per second of all CDPs during market turbulence.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of monitoring the health/status of CDPs.
Assumes regular health checks for CDPs owned by 100 users, with capacity for more frequent updates when needed.
Scales superlinearly due to increased interactions and monitoring complexity with a larger number of agents, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Liquidation Engine
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Liquidation engine checks for undercollateralized CDPs 1 time per second.
Each liquidation action is 450 bytes, accounting for more complex liquidation processes in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Liquidation engine runs continuously, processing 10 checks per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of liquidation actions when CDPs fall below the required collateral ratio.
Assumes a basic liquidation engine capable of managing CDPs for 100 users, with some parallel processing capability.
Scales exponentially as more CDPs fall below the required collateral ratio, triggering liquidations, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Collateral Ratio Adjustments
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Collateral ratios are adjusted 0.5 times per second based on market conditions.
Each adjustment remains at 300 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid market changes require 50 collateral ratio adjustments per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of manual or automatic adjustments to collateral ratios.
Assumes occasional collateral ratio adjustments for CDPs owned by 100 users.
Scales superlinearly as the system requires more frequent adjustments with a higher number of participants, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Collateral ratio management DA increases due to:
• More frequent and precise oracle price updates
• Continuous recalculation of CDP health metrics
• Increased liquidation events requiring immediate action
• Need for real-time global state updates across the network

metrics.name: Stablecoin Minting/Burning

subMetrics.name: Minting Operations
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Users mint new stablecoins 0.2 times per second.
Each minting operation is 450 bytes, accounting for complex minting processes in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in minting results in 20 minting operations per second as users seek stable assets during market downturns.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of stablecoin minting operations.
Assumes moderate minting activity from 100 users, with capacity for increased demand during market stress.
Scales superlinearly as the number of minting operations increases with more participants, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Burning Operations
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Stablecoin burning occurs 0.2 times per second for CDP ratio management.
Each burning operation is 450 bytes, accounting for more complex burning processes in a multi-asset, multi-chain environment.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Mass burning events during deleveraging or confidence loss scenarios lead to 20 burning operations per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of stablecoin burning operations.
Assumes occasional burning operations by CDP owners among the 100 users, with potential for coordinated actions during extreme events.
Scales superlinearly as the number of burning operations increases with more participants, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Supply Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Total supply is recalculated and published 1 time per second.
Each supply management adjustment is 550 bytes, accounting for comprehensive supply management across multiple assets and chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time supply updates during high minting/burning activity result in 30 recalculations per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of adjustments to the overall stablecoin supply to maintain peg stability.
Assumes a basic supply management system capable of handling the minting and burning activity of 100 users.
Scales exponentially as the frequency of supply adjustments increases with more participants to maintain stability, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Transaction Verification
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Transactions are verified at a rate of 5 per second under normal conditions.
Each transaction verification remains at 1300 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High transaction volume requires verification of 20 transactions per second to prevent backlogs.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the verification of transactions related to minting and burning operations.
Assumes standard verification processes suitable for 100 users.
Scales superlinearly due to the need for frequent verifications as the number of transactions grows, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Stablecoin minting/burning DA spikes due to:
• Increased user activity in creating or closing CDPs
• Rapid changes in stablecoin supply requiring system-wide updates
• More frequent checks and adjustments for maintaining the peg
• Need for real-time tracking of global debt ceiling and individual user limits

scenarios.title: Market Volatility and Cross-Chain CDP Management
scenarios.analysis: Rapid market fluctuations lead to cascading liquidations, impacting collateralized debt positions.
scenarios.implications: Ultra-fast cross-chain oracles and predictive modeling are essential to prevent liquidation cascades and maintain system stability.

scenarios.title: Large-Scale Stablecoin Minting/Burning by AI Agents
scenarios.analysis: Coordinated minting and burning activities by AI agents require precise real-time data to balance supply and demand.
scenarios.implications: Real-time system-wide state management is crucial to ensure efficiency and maintain stablecoin peg stability.

scenarios.title: Dynamic Governance for Risk Management
scenarios.analysis: Ongoing governance activities, including parameter changes and risk assessments, require consistent data flow.
scenarios.implications: Efficient cross-chain governance mechanisms are critical to prevent DA congestion and ensure timely decision-making during parameter updates.

scenarios.title: Sudden De-Pegging Events
scenarios.analysis: Rapid de-pegging events trigger emergency actions to restore stability, requiring immediate data access.
scenarios.implications: Robust DA is vital for quick corrective measures, ensuring the stability and confidence in the stablecoin ecosystem.

scenarios.title: Mass Liquidations Due to Collateral Revaluation
scenarios.analysis: Sudden collateral value drops lead to mass liquidations, impacting market conditions.
scenarios.implications: High DA is necessary for efficient liquidation processes, preventing further market destabilization and protecting asset values.

crossChainOperations.name: Cross-Chain Operations
crossChainOperations.explanation: DA requirements for cross-chain operations are influenced by asset transfers between chains, state synchronization challenges, and the complexity of interoperability protocols. Coordinated cross-chain activities and security incidents can lead to significant DA demand surges.

metrics.name: Asset Transfers

subMetrics.name: Transaction Verification
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Cross-chain transactions are verified 5 times per second on average.
Each transaction verification is 350 bytes, accounting for more complex cross-chain verifications.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Verification frequency increases to 50 times per second during high-volume periods.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the verification of transactions related to cross-chain asset transfers.
Assumes occasional cross-chain transactions from the 100 users, with capacity for increased frequency during high activity periods.
Scales superlinearly due to the increased number of transactions and verifications required as more agents participate, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Liquidity Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Liquidity pools for cross-chain assets are rebalanced 2 times per second.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous rebalancing during periods of high transfer volume results in 40 rebalances per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the management of liquidity across chains to ensure smooth transfers.
Assumes moderate-sized liquidity pools suitable for cross-chain activity of 100 users, with adaptability for volume spikes.
Each liquidity management action is 450 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive liquidity management across multiple chains.
Scales exponentially as the complexity of managing liquidity across chains increases with more participants, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Fee Calculation
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Transfer fees are recalculated 2 times per second based on network conditions.
Each fee calculation remains at 250 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time fee adjustments during congestion or attack scenarios lead to 20 recalculations per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the calculation of fees for cross-chain transactions.
Assumes a basic fee calculation system capable of handling the cross-chain transaction volume from 100 users.
Scales superlinearly with the number of transactions requiring fee calculations, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Transaction Finality Confirmation
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Cross-chain transaction finality is confirmed 1 time per second.
Each finality confirmation is 250 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive confirmation data.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Finality confirmation rate increases to 100 times per second during high-activity periods.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the confirmation that cross-chain transactions have reached finality.
Assumes standard finality confirmation processes for cross-chain transactions involving 100 users.
Scales superlinearly as more transactions require finality confirmations, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Asset transfer DA increases due to:
• Higher frequency of cross-chain transaction verifications
• Rapid updates to liquidity pools across multiple chains
• More complex fee calculations considering multi-chain conditions
• Need for real-time tracking of in-flight transactions across chains

metrics.name: State Synchronization

subMetrics.name: Block Header Relay
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Block headers are relayed between chains 1 time per second.
Each block header relay is 1,200 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive block headers.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Header relay frequency increases to 10 times per second during high-activity periods.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of block header relays between chains.
Assumes regular block header relay suitable for the cross-chain activity level of 100 users, with ability to increase frequency when needed.
Scales exponentially as the number of relays increases with more participants, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Merkle Proof Verification
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Merkle proofs for cross-chain data are verified 2 times per second.
Each Merkle proof verification remains at 320 bytes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous proof verification during large-scale cross-chain operations leads to 20 verifications per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the verification of Merkle proofs for cross-chain transactions.
Assumes periodic Merkle proof verifications for the expected cross-chain data volume from 100 users, with capacity for continuous verification during peak times.
Scales superlinearly with the number of transactions requiring verification, but with optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Consensus Mechanism Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Validator set changes are propagated across chains 0.5 times per second.
Each consensus update is 10,000 bytes, accounting for more complex consensus updates across multiple chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid validator set updates during network attacks or failures result in 5 updates per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the updates to the consensus mechanism across chains.
Assumes a basic consensus mechanism with infrequent updates, suitable for managing cross-chain operations for 100 users.
Scales exponentially due to the need for frequent updates to maintain consensus across chains, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: State Commitments
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
State commitments are made 1 time per second to ensure consistency.
Each state commitment is 320 bytes, accounting for a comprehensive state commitments, 32 bytes for the hash (e.g., SHA-256), across up to 10 chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Commitment frequency increases to 10 times per second during high cross-chain activity.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of state commitments to ensure consistency across chains.
Assumes regular state commitment processes suitable for managing cross-chain consistency for 100 users.
Scales superlinearly as the complexity of maintaining state consistency increases, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
State synchronization DA spikes due to:
• Increased frequency of block header relays between chains
• More complex and frequent Merkle proof verifications
• Rapid propagation of consensus mechanism updates across chains
• Need for maintaining consistent state across multiple blockchain networks

metrics.name: Interoperability Protocol Management

subMetrics.name: Protocol Version Control
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Interoperability protocol versions are checked 0.1 times per second across all integrated chains.
Each protocol version update is 1,000 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive version control data.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time version checks and updates during critical protocol upgrades result in 10 checks per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency of updates and management of protocol versions across chains.
Assumes basic version control mechanisms suitable for managing interoperability for 100 users across a limited number of integrated chains.
Scales logarithmically as the number of agents increases, reflecting optimizations and less frequent updates relative to the number of agents at scale.

subMetrics.name: Cross-Chain Contract Calls
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Cross-chain smart contract calls are processed 1 time per second.
Each cross-chain contract call is 1,500 bytes, accounting for more complex cross-chain calls.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous processing of contract calls during multi-chain DApp events results in 100 calls per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the frequency and size of contract calls between chains.
Assumes occasional cross-chain contract calls from the 100 users, with capacity to handle increased frequency during popular DApp events.
Scales exponentially as the number of contract calls increases with more participants, but with slight optimizations at scale.

subMetrics.name: Bridging Security Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample:
Security audits of bridge contracts are performed 0.5 times per second.
Each security monitoring event is 500 bytes, accounting for more comprehensive security monitoring across multiple chains and bridges.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous monitoring and real-time alerts during suspected bridge exploits lead to 50 audits per second.
subMetrics.assumptions:
Measures the monitoring and management of security for cross-chain bridges.
Assumes basic security monitoring for cross-chain bridges, suitable for the activity level of 100 users, with enhanced monitoring capabilities during security events.
Scales superlinearly as the complexity of security monitoring increases with more participants, but with optimizations at scale.

metrics.explanation:
Interoperability protocol management DA requirements increase due to:
• Need for consistent protocol versions across multiple chains
• Increased complexity and frequency of cross-chain contract calls
• Enhanced security monitoring of bridge contracts and transactions
• Rapid response mechanisms for cross-chain security incidents

scenarios.title: Cross-Chain Security Incidents
scenarios.analysis: Security breaches require immediate DA to propagate alerts and facilitate rapid response across chains.
scenarios.implications: Robust, real-time data availability is crucial to contain threats and ensure network integrity, preventing cascading failures.

scenarios.title: Massive Cross-Chain Asset Transfers
scenarios.analysis: Large volumes of asset transfers increase DA requirements for transaction verifications and liquidity management.
scenarios.implications: Scalable DA systems are essential to handle increased transaction loads, ensuring seamless asset movements and preventing bottlenecks.

scenarios.title: Simultaneous Protocol Upgrades
scenarios.analysis: Protocol upgrades across multiple chains demand synchronized version control and increased DA for updates.
scenarios.implications: Enhanced DA is needed to manage version compatibility and ensure smooth protocol transitions, maintaining network stability.

scenarios.title: Coordinated Cross-Chain Arbitrage
scenarios.analysis: AI agents exploit price differences across chains, requiring rapid data access and transaction execution.
scenarios.implications: Immediate DA is crucial for efficient trade execution, minimizing arbitrage risks and maintaining market efficiency.

scenarios.title: Rapid Onboarding of New Chains
scenarios.analysis: Integrating new chains into existing networks requires increased DA for protocol compatibility and data synchronization.
scenarios.implications: Scalable DA solutions are essential to ensure seamless onboarding and maintain interoperability across networks.

scenarios.title: Dynamic Bridging Mechanisms
scenarios.analysis: Frequent updates to bridging protocols necessitate continuous DA to support secure and efficient cross-chain transactions.
scenarios.implications: Robust DA is vital for maintaining bridge security and optimizing transaction flows, ensuring reliable cross-chain interactions.
